infodynamics.measures.continuous.kozachenko

Class EntropyCalculatorMultiVariateKozachenko

  • java.lang.Object
    • infodynamics.measures.continuous.kozachenko.EntropyCalculatorMultiVariateKozachenko
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    EntropyCalculator, EntropyCalculatorMultiVariate, InfoMeasureCalculatorContinuous

    public class EntropyCalculatorMultiVariateKozachenko
extends java.lang.Object
implements EntropyCalculatorMultiVariate

    Computes the differential entropy of a given set of observations (implementing EntropyCalculatorMultiVariate, using the Kozachenko-Leonenko estimator. For details, see references below. This class computes it exactly as in the paper by Kraskov et al. below, i.e. using natural units and twice the minimum distance.

    Usage is as per the paradigm outlined for EntropyCalculatorMultiVariate, with:

    • The constructor step being a simple call to EntropyCalculatorMultiVariateKozachenko().
    • An additional setObservations(double[][], double[][]) option;

    References:

    • Kozachenko, L., Leonenko, N., "A statistical estimate for the entropy of a random vector", Problems of Information Transmission, 23 (1987) 9-16.
    • Kraskov, A., Stoegbauer, H., Grassberger, P., "Estimating mutual information", Physical Review E 69, (2004) 066138.
    • George Mathews, Hugh Durrant-Whyte, and Mikhail Prokopenko, "Measuring Global Behaviour of Multi-Agent Systems from Pair-Wise Mutual Information", Knowledge-Based Intelligent Information and Engineering Systems, Lecture Notes in Computer Science Volume 3684, 2005, pp 587-594.
    Author:
    Joseph Lizier (email, www)

      Property name for whether to normalise the incoming data to mean 0, standard deviation 1 (default true)

      • setProperty

        public void setProperty(java.lang.String propertyName,
               java.lang.String propertyValue)
                 throws java.lang.Exception
        Description copied from interface: EntropyCalculatorMultiVariate
        Set properties for the underlying calculator implementation. New property values are not guaranteed to take effect until the next call to an initialise method.

        Property names defined at the interface level, and what their values should represent, include:

        • EntropyCalculatorMultiVariate.NUM_DIMENSIONS_PROP_NAME -- number of dimensions in the joint variable that we are computing the entropy of.

        Unknown property values are ignored.

        Note that implementing classes may defined additional properties.

        Specified by:

      • addObservations

        public void addObservations(double[][] data1,
                   double[][] data2)
                     throws java.lang.Exception
        Each row of the data is an observation; each column of the row is a new variable in the multivariate observation. This method signature allows the user to call setObservations for joint time series without combining them into a single joint time series (we do the combining for them).
        Parameters:
        data1 - first few variables in the joint data
        data2 - the other variables in the joint data
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - When the length of the two arrays of observations do not match.
        See Also:
        addObservations(double[][])

      • getNumObservations

        public int getNumObservations()
        Description copied from interface: InfoMeasureCalculatorContinuous
        Get the number of samples to be used for the PDFs here which have been supplied by calls to "setObservations", "addObservations" etc.

        Note that the number of samples may not be equal to the length of time-series supplied (e.g. for transfer entropy, where we need to accumulate a number of samples for the past history of the destination).

        Specified by:
        getNumObservations in interface InfoMeasureCalculatorContinuous
        Returns:
        the number of samples to be used for the PDFs
